questions.query: Email Address
questions.explanation: mac@macbudkowski.com

questions.query: Telegram Handle We Can Use To Contact You
questions.explanation: macbudkowski

questions.query: Project GitHub Repo
questions.explanation: https://github.com/attestate/kiwistand

questions.query: Link to your Public Group Chat
questions.explanation: https://t.me/kiwinewsdevs

questions.query: Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile associated with previous rounds.
questions.explanation:
Yes, we participated in GG20, GG22, Octant and ENS rounds. 

Here's the link to our builder profile:
https://builder.gitcoin.co/#/chains/10/registry/0x/projects/0x19b8fdb6bdea6cdb71a19f43c0ec0962ec08b563c57f4c2307d0b954123dd67e

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the growth of the OSS ecosystem? Please provide specific examples of how your application enhances or expands the current ecosystem.
questions.explanation:
Everything on Kiwi - since Day 1 - is 100% open source. 

Devs can look into our front-end, back-end and P2P protocol code. 

We also do a lot of R&D work - so far we shipped key delegation, implemented passkeys and designed onchain ads and everything is publicly available for other projects to use.

We are also running an open devs chat where we discuss our technical decisions. Everyone can join, ask questions and contribute.

questions.query: What features or use cases does your dApp/App present? How is it differentiated?
questions.explanation:
Kiwi is a space for people who care about Ethereum, beyond its price.

It’s an app where everyone can follow the most important ETH ideas and projects without Twitter noise. 

Every month our community of 100+ Ethereum power users goes through hundreds of tweets, blogposts, dashboards, newsletters and products, to surface the ones that stand out. 

Everyone can join them and start sharing, upvoting, and discussing the links with our community. Everyone can also just read Kiwi and join our 2,000+ monthly readers.

So Kiwi is basically Ethereum Hacker News. It is differentiated because other projects are either curated by one person (Telegram channels like Cookie Reads) or focused on different type of content (social networks like Farcaster, Lens).

questions.query: What are your plans for further development, and how will the grant funds be used to achieve these goals?
questions.explanation:
We found out that comments are the most important element of our app, because they help readers better understand ETH ideas, dashboards and products.

So right now we want to improve the comments - so far we shipped emoji reactions and notifications, and now we want to improve the speed and stability of commenting, to make the experience closer to real-time Telegram conversations. 

This is technically challenging and will take at least a few weeks - if not months - of development.

Since there are only the two of us and we want to ship fast, there are also some bugs and smaller improvements that we need to fix to make our users happier.

Please include a separate line for each unique deployer address and blockchain combination.

data.name: Gitcoin
data.description: Gitcoin creates solutions that empower digitally native communities to fund, build, and protect what matters.

questions.query: If you've participated in past grant rounds, please share any new updates or milestones from the prior months (N/A if you are yet to participate).
questions.explanation: Since the last round (GG20), we redesigned our app, organized writing contests with Gnosis & Lens, made comments more visible inside the feed, and optimized the app’s performance.

questions.query: Have you participated in any Octant epoch (Epoch 0 through Epoch 4) OR a previous Gitcoin Grants round? Please provide details and evidence of your participation.
questions.explanation: We participated in Gitcoin Rounds [#18](https://explorer.gitcoin.co/#/projects/0xba1c6642d56c43d020777a42f2291a8e150395fb8d7000b3ffccb40462aedade) and [#20](https://explorer.gitcoin.co/#/projects/0x19b8fdb6bdea6cdb71a19f43c0ec0962ec08b563c57f4c2307d0b954123dd67e)

questions.query: Please describe how your project contributes to the growth and development of the Octant ecosystem.
questions.explanation:
Kiwi helps Ethereum builders find quality crypto content. From top news, essays, and products up to Dune dashboards, GitHub repos & security breach case studies.

We believe that quality content feeds & conversations that are not limited to quick dunks on Twitter are essential for the broader Ethereum community.

The Kiwi community often shares & discusses [ideas related to public goods funding](https://www.google.com/search?q=public+goods+site%3Anews.kiwistand.com&sca_esv=3e171935153702ef&sca_upv=1&sxsrf=ADLYWIKfSFcDUn4AEKqNMvl1SGln50UniA%3A1726052477854&ei=fXjhZqPjM5CG7NYP1aKB4QY&ved=0ahUKEwjjlbnG3rqIAxUQA9sEHVVRIGwQ4dUDCA8&uact=5&oq=public+goods+site%3Anews.kiwistand.com&gs_lp=Egxnd3Mtd2l6LXNlcnAiJHB1YmxpYyBnb29kcyBzaXRlOm5ld3Mua2l3aXN0YW5kLmNvbUi5DFAAWLYKcAB4AJABAJgBbKABjAiqAQQxMS4xuAEDyAEA-AEBmAIAoAIAmAMAkgcAoAecBA&sclient=gws-wiz-serp), which helps to educate our readers about its impact and complexities.

What’s more, we offered Octant projects free onboarding, which means they could share their updates on Kiwi and join our community of 500+ crypto founders, devs & creators who are in crypto for the right reasons.

questions.query: How does your project align with the round's focus on community and education within the Octant ecosystem?
questions.explanation:
For the last 1.5 years, we have been sharing high-quality crypto content via our app (read by 1,400+ crypto natives per month) and our weekly newsletter (read by 1,200+ people per month). 

On top of that, we have been building a supportive 500+ people community of crypto devs, founders & creators.

questions.query: Provide a clear roadmap of your project, detailing future milestones and deliverables. How does this demonstrate your commitment to long-term impact and growth within the Octant ecosystem?
questions.explanation:
Here are things that we want to work on in the next few months:

1) Onchain ads.

We’ve recently launched onchain ads powered by Harberger tax. There isn’t a user interface yet, so our customers currently have to use Etherscan to set up ads. We already had some customers using them, but we want to make the UX much easier.

With the funding, we want to build a simple user interface to grow the revenue generated from these ads. We also want to work on designing and marketing the offer to customers. We’ve seen that providing white glove service to potential customers is a way to get them engaged in running a campaign.

2) Drive growth to the product.

The unromantic reality of building a social media protocol is that without people using the product, there also won’t be anyone using the protocol. Hence, we are pursuing a dual-focus strategy. We believe in building the protocol over the long term, but short term this means making the product so good that it drives the usage of the protocol.

As for how to drive the product, this is based on adjusting configurations in the right places to increase retention, the onboarding throughput and so on. It’s not straight forward, but the processes is such that, one day, we actually become independent from being funded by grants.

3) Harden the protocol.

Kiwi News is built on a p2p protocol. It needs constant maintenance with more and more people running nodes and using the product. Our goal here is to harden the protocol such that we are as good as possible prepared for when more people will start using us.

questions.query: Describe your team's expertise and how it contributes to the successful execution of your project.
questions.explanation:
Tim Daubenschutz (Tech & Product) 
- Worked on the precursor of NFTs @ ascribe.io [2015], 
- Co-created Soulbound tokens. Authored EIP-4973, EIP-5192 & ERC-4973 Reference Implementation 
- Ran rugpullindex to protect investors from rug pulls

Mac Budkowski (Community & Growth) 
- Founded & hosted web3 talks - one of the most popular builders-oriented crypto podcasts,
- Co-built Goerlinator that distributed 20,000 GoerliETH to Ethereum builders and was mentioned in Week in Ethereum News 
- Used to run a marketing agency.

We have been working together for 1.5 years and have been able to build everything just with the two of us and support from our community.

questions.query: How does your project complement or enhance existing initiatives within the Octant ecosystem rather than competing directly against them?
questions.explanation: Kiwi can be used by anyone looking for crypto content for builders. Octant projects can also use Kiwi to share their links and receive extra distribution among crypto natives.

questions.query: Describe your approach to community engagement and how you plan to contribute to a collaborative and constructive funding environment.
questions.explanation:
We treat the community very seriously because it’s a critical element of our project. So, our community is being engaged via our app (by submitting, upvoting, and commenting on links every day) and a Telegram group chat where we co-create the product with our users.

We also share our community-building learnings via [articles](https://kanfa.macbudkowski.com/community-building-lessons-kiwi) and [talks](https://cfp.ethwarsaw.dev/ethwarsaw-2024/talk/7WCCQX/)

When it comes to funding, we rejected VC offers and decided to build an independent social media project based on public goods funding & revenue. If we succeed in that path, our story could encourage other builders to follow this path - just like ENS has been an inspiration to us.

questions.query: How do you plan to use the funding to maximize your project's ongoing impact within the Octant ecosystem if selected?
questions.explanation: All funding will go to the ongoing development of the Kiwi app & protocol. We’d also be happy to educate Octant projects on how they can use Kiwi to spread the word about their actions.

questions.query: What unique educational content or resources have you created for the Octant ecosystem? How has the community received these? Please share any relevant links
questions.explanation:
Since we are a link aggregator, we primarily helped distribute the content already created - some [examples can be found here](https://www.google.com/search?q=octant+site%3Anews.kiwistand.com&oq=octant+site%3Anews.kiwistand.com&gs_lcrp=EgZjaHJvbWUyBggAEEUYOTIGCAEQLhhA0gEIODUzMGowajSoAgCwAgE&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8)

On top of that, we did some [announcement posts](https://x.com/KiwiNewsHQ/status/1830615487467958775), and Mac educated people about Octant in a few group chats.

data.text:
What we did at Kiwi for our Octant milestones since the last October 3rd update:

1) ### Onchain ads

**a. We have first paying clients**

We spoke with a few potential clients, and some of them decided to test our ads with real money. Among our clients are Oku.trade, Smolrefuel, and Superscan. We haven’t made a lot yet - about $32 so far - but it’s nice to see that people are eager to pay for it.

Everything is onchain so you can [check the contract here](https://optimistic.etherscan.io/address/0x2e78Fad843177343Feb2f1d5cb9699A061C59c06). 

**b. We had a talk at Devcon related to the mechanism behind the ad.**

Tim Daub (my co-founder) worked on laying out the theoretical foundations for the ads mechanism, and he consulted Matt Prewitt from RadicalxChange.

He wrote the first [draft of the whitepaper](https://github.com/attestate/ad/blob/main/whitepaper.md).

And had a Devcon talk you can watch here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pjcP-P7q5mU 

**c. We shipped some small improvements.**

We gathered client feedback and made it easier to understand how the ad works, made it more visual, and changed the pricing so that it’s now cheaper to run an ad.


### 2) Driving growth

**a. We organized two writing contests.**

The first contest was with Nouns.

We received many high-quality submissions from both the nouns and people in our community. This action helped us reach the Nouns community - we were mentioned in the Nouns newsletters, podcasts, and on their Farcaster channel.

You can read the submissions and learn about the results here:
https://paragraph.xyz/@kiwi-updates/into-the-nouniverse-writing-contest-results


The second contest is still running, and it’s organized with Gnosis.

This one is based on the debates from Devconflict, with discussions from people like Vitalik, Martin Koeppelmann, Toni Wahrstätter from EF, Nixo from EthStaker, and many more. The idea is simple - you watch the discussion recording and share your opinion.

You can watch the talks and learn about the contest here:
https://paragraph.xyz/@kiwi-updates/arena-devconflict-writing-contest 

**b. We went to Devcon.**

At Devcon, we spoke with many potential partners. We can’t share the details yet, but the future looks promising!

We also did a DIP with Devcon where some users could get a free Kiwi Pass, and all attendees could use ZuPass to get -24% off.

https://paragraph.xyz/@kiwi-updates/become-a-kiwi-devcon-reporter


**c. We improved the product**

Our community member - rvolz.eth - built a search engine that indexes our 11,000+ links and almost 3,000 comments. 

You can check all Octant-related posts and [play around with it here](https://knsearch.x4901.xyz/?query=octant&comments=false&sort=freshness).

We also added a better comments preview in the feed, which helped us increase the amount of comments we receive. 

We also spent a lot of time improving the caching so that your app can work very fast.


### 3) Protocol hardening

We had some memory leaks in the nodes, and we worked hard with rvolz.eth to fix them. The good news is that right now, we have fewer bugs and problems than we had before. It's also much easier to run a node.

***

It was a very productive time, and we put much effort into making things happen. Octant funding helped us a lot. So we do hope we can raise even more in the next Epoch and get more Ethereum community members to read and discuss all quality Ethereum content on Kiwi :)
data.title: Our updates until the 29th of November

data.text:
Some updates from Kiwi from the last 1.5 months.

We said in our Octant application that we want to focus on three priorities:
1) onchain ads
2) driving growth
3) hardening the protocol


We ofc didn't want to wait for the Octant grant to start working, so here are some updates on our progress:

### 1) Onchain ads

**a. onchain ad UI**

We built the first prototype of the [ad's UI](https://news.kiwistand.com/submit) *(you can see it by clicking "Submit story as an ad")*.

**b. updated ad's contract**

We updated the [ad's contract](https://github.com/attestate/ad/commit/e9f699e6c03dd71363fe93c0bb89d2043f1d9390#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5R30) based on our users' feedback.

### 2) Driving growth

**a. Writing contest**

We organized a month-long writing contest with Lens called "Pluralistic Future of L2s". 

The contest got a [lot of attention](https://x.com/KiwiNewsHQ/status/1828834946204701180/photo/1), and we even got a [prompt from Vitalik](https://x.com/VitalikButerin/status/1828843846496813109).

We received 28 submissions from a diverse group of authors, including the co-inventor of the ERC20 standard, co-founder of Celo, and Ethereum Foundation researcher. 

And the writers' work got a lot of eyeballs. We calculated with t2 that people spent over 20 hours reading the submissions, and some contest essays have been read by [Vitalik](https://twitter.com/VitalikButerin/status/1838809754002690403), [Stani Kulechov](https://x.com/StaniKulechov/status/1838886110509883876), and [Alex Glukhovsky](https://x.com/gluk64/status/1838930538993680610). 

The contest was also successful from the growth POV - since the beginning it, we got [54 new paying users](https://optimistic.etherscan.io/token/0x66747bdc903d17c586fa09ee5d6b54cc85bbea45). 

If you want to dig in, you can read some of my [favorite contest ideas here](https://x.com/MacBudkowski/status/1838607991995596839). We are also going to organize another writing contest with Nouns.

**b. Improving the product**

We added images [to the feed](https://news.kiwistand.com/).

Fixed [notifications bugs](https://github.com/attestate/kiwistand/commit/ea45787e271514750fdb5abe5fa6972b1f155edd).

And started showing the number of clicks for all links.

We also started prompting Base & Arbitrum users to bridge to OP to get a Kiwi Pass.

**c. Promotion**

We integrated [Farcaster Frames](https://warpcast.com/casslineth/0x64904cd8).

Kiwi got featured [among Warpcast apps](https://warpcast.com/macbudkowski/0xadb4dbb4).

We also improved referrals so that when you invite a friend, they get a % off, and you get a bit of ETH.

We also got a [new version of the Kiwi Dune dashboard](https://dune.com/rvolz/kiwi-news), maintained by our contributor - rvolz.eth.

### 3) Protocol hardening

In terms of protocol hardening, we were primarily focused on debugging the protocol code with rvolz.eth, who runs a node.

There were many commits related to that challenge, and some of them took a lot of investigation even though the commits [were short](https://github.com/attestate/kiwistand/commit/7b5eef297e5499c59a9b860502ee2e765809cfc4).

***


All in all, we had a very productive 1.5 months and did a lot to move forward.
data.title: Our updates until the October 3rd

data.text:
We achieved all three milestones (& more) that we mentioned in our Octant application.

> Milestone #1: Onchain Ads
> 
> Deliverables: A simple user interface that lets publishers post ads on Kiwi. We would also have a simple moderation system to prevent ads from being used by malicious actors.
>Expected Outcome: By setting up the user interface, we can generate real revenue from ads and become more financially sustainable.
> 

We delivered the user interface, we got the first paying users, and we optimized the ads' contract and the way its displayed based on the users' feedback.


> Milestone #2: Driving product growth 
> 
> Deliverables: Implement a better design, improve the onboarding and pricing mechanism, signify more clearly how active people are on Kiwi.
> 
> Expected Outcome: By increasing the number of users and our retention rate, we can serve our mission better and also generate more money via ads, and other opportunities.

We improved the design based on conversations with our users: there's a fresh design with new contrast, we display comments in a much more engaging way, and since our users are more prone to comment which is one of our main retention metrics [https://news.kiwistand.com/basics]


> Milestone #3: Protocol hardening: [1 ETH]
> 
> Deliverables: Fix a bug that currently makes it impossible for a newly joined node to sync the entire data set.
> 
> Expected Outcome: This will make it easier to further decentralize our protocol and let our community run nodes.

We fixed this bug (and a few others) and also have a node setup tutorial (https://github.com/x4901/kiwi-news-deploy)

data.name: Octant
data.description: Octant is a platform that enables users to lock GLM, earn ETH rewards, and fund projects they care about.

questions.query: Project GitHub Repo
questions.explanation: https://github.com/attestate/kiwistand

questions.query: Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile associated with previous rounds.
questions.explanation: Yes, we participated in Gitcoin Rounds:  #18: https://explorer.gitcoin.co/#/projects/0xba1c6642d56c43d020777a42f2291a8e150395fb8d7000b3ffccb40462aedade   and #20: https://explorer.gitcoin.co/#/projects/0x19b8fdb6bdea6cdb71a19f43c0ec0962ec08b563c57f4c2307d0b954123dd67e   as well as Gitcoin x Octant Community round: https://explorer.gitcoin.co/#/round/10/66/52

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the growth of the OSS ecosystem? Please provide specific examples of how your application enhances or expands the current ecosystem.
questions.explanation:
Our front-end, back-end, and protocol are fully open source under GPL-3.0 license.

Here are some specific projects we delivered:

We built one of the first open-source Passkeys implementations: https://kiwistand.github.io/kiwi-docs/docs/kiwi-how-works/passkeys 

We created an open-source key delegation implementation:

https://kiwistand.github.io/kiwi-docs/docs/kiwi-how-works/delegation 

We created an open-source onchain ads prototype:
https://github.com/attestate/ad 

And on top of that, we support indie devs in sharing their projects with a wider audience:
https://kiwistand.github.io/kiwi-docs/docs/community/sharing-products

questions.query: What features or use cases does your dApp/App present? How is it differentiated?
questions.explanation:
Kiwi is a crypto Hacker News - it helps Ethereum builders find quality crypto content. From top news, essays, and products up to Dune dashboards, GitHub repos & security breach case studies. 

Our feed is curated by the community. This means that our 120+ monthly curators go through hundreds of crypto sources - newsletters, podcasts, telegram channels, group chats, and so on - to share, upvote, and comment on the most interesting and relevant crypto content.

Kiwi also helps crypto builders meet like-minded people - they can join our community of 500+ crypto devs, founders, creators & investors.

We also support crypto writers with contests where they can write about crypto-related subjects and win USDC or ETH. 

The contests are organized in our app and the last contest about L2s - co-organized with Lens - even received a [prompt from Vitalik](https://paragraph.xyz/@kiwi-updates/pluralistic-future-of-l2s-results).

questions.query: What are your plans for further development, and how will the grant funds be used to achieve these goals?
questions.explanation:
Kiwi has three main goals:

1) We want become more financially sustainable. 

That’s why we are exploring different revenue streams. At the moment, we are working on improving the onchain ad, which already generated some small revenue from our community members promoting their products. 

2) We want to grow the app’s usage.

We plan to improve the UX, onboarding, and user retention. It will take lots of experiments and developers' time before we nail it.

3) We want to harden the protocol.

Kiwi is an app that’s built on top of a P2P protocol. 
It needs constant maintenance with more and more people running nodes and using the product. Our goal here is to harden the protocol such that we are as good as possible prepared for when more people will start using us.

***
We want to use the Gitcoin grant to cover the costs of working on Kiwi since we are bootstrapped and live off revenue & grants.

data.name: ENS
data.description: The GG20 ENS Identity Round round is meant to support projects actively building on top of ENS. Any project that is growing, enhancing, or supporting the decentralized identity system around ENS is eligible.
We received 1.77ETH and had 43 donors contributing to the matching pool.
data.title: Octant - Epoch 5

data.title: Update: 3rd October 2024 - 29th November 2024

data.text:
Some updates from Kiwi from the last 1.5 months.

We said in our Octant application that we want to focus on three priorities:
1) onchain ads
2) driving growth
3) hardening the protocol


We ofc didn't want to wait for the Octant grant to start working, so here are some updates on our progress:

### 1) Onchain ads

**a. onchain ad UI**

We built the first prototype of the [ad's UI](https://news.kiwistand.com/submit) *(you can see it by clicking "Submit story as an ad")*.

**b. updated ad's contract**

We updated the [ad's contract](https://github.com/attestate/ad/commit/e9f699e6c03dd71363fe93c0bb89d2043f1d9390#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5R30) based on our users' feedback.

### 2) Driving growth

**a. Writing contest**

We organized a month-long writing contest with Lens called "Pluralistic Future of L2s". 

The contest got a [lot of attention](https://x.com/KiwiNewsHQ/status/1828834946204701180/photo/1), and we even got a [prompt from Vitalik](https://x.com/VitalikButerin/status/1828843846496813109).

We received 28 submissions from a diverse group of authors, including the co-inventor of the ERC20 standard, co-founder of Celo, and Ethereum Foundation researcher. 

And the writers' work got a lot of eyeballs. We calculated with t2 that people spent over 20 hours reading the submissions, and some contest essays have been read by [Vitalik](https://twitter.com/VitalikButerin/status/1838809754002690403), [Stani Kulechov](https://x.com/StaniKulechov/status/1838886110509883876), and [Alex Glukhovsky](https://x.com/gluk64/status/1838930538993680610). 

The contest was also successful from the growth POV - since the beginning it, we got [54 new paying users](https://optimistic.etherscan.io/token/0x66747bdc903d17c586fa09ee5d6b54cc85bbea45). 

If you want to dig in, you can read some of my [favorite contest ideas here](https://x.com/MacBudkowski/status/1838607991995596839). We are also going to organize another writing contest with Nouns.

**b. Improving the product**

We added images [to the feed](https://news.kiwistand.com/).

Fixed [notifications bugs](https://github.com/attestate/kiwistand/commit/ea45787e271514750fdb5abe5fa6972b1f155edd).

And started showing the number of clicks for all links.

We also started prompting Base & Arbitrum users to bridge to OP to get a Kiwi Pass.

**c. Promotion**

We integrated [Farcaster Frames](https://warpcast.com/casslineth/0x64904cd8).

Kiwi got featured [among Warpcast apps](https://warpcast.com/macbudkowski/0xadb4dbb4).

We also improved referrals so that when you invite a friend, they get a % off, and you get a bit of ETH.

We also got a [new version of the Kiwi Dune dashboard](https://dune.com/rvolz/kiwi-news), maintained by our contributor - rvolz.eth.

### 3) Protocol hardening

In terms of protocol hardening, we were primarily focused on debugging the protocol code with rvolz.eth, who runs a node.

There were many commits related to that challenge, and some of them took a lot of investigation even though the commits [were short](https://github.com/attestate/kiwistand/commit/7b5eef297e5499c59a9b860502ee2e765809cfc4).

***


All in all, we had a very productive 1.5 months and did a lot to move forward.

We do hope that with the Octant funding, we will be able to take our efforts to the next level and get more Ethereum community members to read and discuss all quality Ethereum content on Kiwi - our decentralized crypto Hacker News.
